entry.content:

Markdown Extension Web Extensions Node



2022/1/8
 @mdx/mdx-loader next.config.js Dynamic import
 
  mdx Run MDX

 useSWR
  content compiledContent run()
  await fetcher




 zenn-editor md MDX
 getStatic*zenn-editor
 zenn-editor markdownToHTML MDX article, book zeroconfig

pages/blog/[id].tsx getStaticPath map file
getStaticProps process.env.NODE_ENV props
process.env.NODE_ENV
 dev: useSWR /api/blog/[id]
 prod: props dangerouslySetInnerHTML
   
 MDXremark-zenn-plugin
  zenn-editor
   
---

remark-zenn-plugin

Blog main
  dev Blog useSWR
  commitPRcommit API
 deploy prod main getStatic*
  SSGISRdev API Route next dev server zenn-cli/src/server
   express.js



MDX MD HTML zenn-markdownhtml + zenn-content-css + zenn-embed-elements


@mdx-js/mdx is a unified pipeline wrapped so that most folks dont need to know about unified: core.js#L65. The processor goes through these steps:

1. Parse MDX (serialized markdown with embedded JSX, ESM, and expressions) to mdast (markdown syntax tree)
2. Transform through remark (markdown ecosystem)
3. Transform mdast to hast (HTML syntax tree)
4. Transform through rehype (HTML ecosystem)
5. Transform hast to esast (JS syntax tree)
5. Do the work needed to get a component
6. Transform through recma (JS ecosystem)
7. Serialize esast as JavaScript

JS plain text

MDX markdown JS

unified Markdown mdast paragraph > text markdown
zenn-markdown-html remark-zenn-plugin
 mdasthttps://github.com/syntax-tree/mdast

text htmlText mdast

Admonition remark-admonitions

entry.title: env vs Runtime Configuration - - Scrapbox
entry.content:
#Nextjs

 environment-variables
 runtime-configuration

Generally you'll want to use build-time environment variables to provide your configuration. The reason for this is that runtime configuration adds rendering / initialization overhead and is incompatible with Automatic Static Optimization.
Automatic Static Optimization

next.js runtime config env

code:Ikuno.rq
 prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#>
 prefix xsd: <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#>
 prefix netkeiba: <https://db.netkeiba.com/>
 prefix horse: <https://db.netkeiba.com/horse/>
 prefix trainer: <https://db.netkeiba.com/trainer/>
 prefix owner: <https://db.netkeiba.com/owner/>
 prefix breeder: <https://db.netkeiba.com/breeder/>
 
 prefix relation: <https://db.netkeiba.com/horse/ped#>
 prefix race: <https://db.netkeiba.com/race/>
 
 select ?race
 where {
   horse:1987104784 horse:race_history/rdf:rest*/rdf:first ?race .
 }


code:all_graph
 # endpoint
 SELECT DISTINCT ?g
 WHERE {
   GRAPH ?g {?s ?p ?o}
 }
 ORDER BY ?g



NumberOfBuffers = 160000
MaxDirtyBuffers = 120000
rdf_loader_run() * 1;

entry.title: Container-Optimized OS - - Scrapbox
entry.content:
#GCE #GCP

GCP Container-Optimized OS tips | gotohayato.com

cloud-config user-data 256KB
 

startup-script startup-script-url
 

cf. GCE startup/shutdown script - Qiita


Docker Compose

a) Custom metadata user-data daemon
b) Custom metadata startup-script

cloud-init
startup-script startup-script-url GCS
 cloud-init start-up

/home/username/myapp/ docker-compose.yml docker-compose up -d

/home/username/myapp/ gsutil GCS

VM metadata ENV_FILE .env startup-script.env
 endpoint http://metadata.google.internal/computeMetadata/v1/
  ENV_FILE=$(curl http://metadata.google.internal/computeMetadata/v1/instance/attributes/database_name -H "Metadata-Flavor: Google") echo $ENV_FILE > /path/to/.env
 docker-compose.yml

docker-compose.yml COMPOSE_FILE


user-data, startup-script, ENV_FILE, COMPOSE_FILE

user-data cloud-config
startup-scriptcloud-config
ENV_FILE docker-compose.yml .env startup-script
COMPOSE_FILEdocker-compose.yml startup-script


code:cloud-config.yml
 # clout-init
 




# http-server
code:terminal
 cd ~/ML4Keiba && \
 source ./.env && \
 gcloud compute instances create $INSTANCE_NAME \
   --image cos-93-16623-39-6 \
   --image-project cos-cloud \
   --zone us-east4-c \
   --tags http-server,https-server \
   --machine-type e2-small \
   --boot-disk-size 15 \
   --boot-disk-type pd-standard \
   --boot-disk-device-name $INSTANCE_NAME \
   --metadata-from-file user-data=$PWD/gcp/cloud-config.yml,nginx_conf=$PWD/nginx/default.conf.template,dotenv=$PWD/.env,docker_compose=$PWD/docker-compose.yml,startup-script=$PWD/gcp/startup.sh \
   --metadata cos-metrics-enabled=true,USERNAME=kiai \
   --address $STATIC_IP_ADDRESS
    

code:terminal
 cd ~/ML4Keiba && \
 source ./.env && \
 gcloud compute instances create $GCE_INSTANCE_NAME \
 --project $GCE_PROJECT_NAME \
 --zone $GCE_ZONE \
 --machine-type $GCE_MACHINE_TYPE \
 --tags $GCE_TAGS \
 --create-disk $GCE_CREATE_DISK \
 --metadata-from-file NGINX_CONFIG=$PWD/nginx/default.conf.template,DOTENV=$PWD/.env,COMPOSE_FILE=$PWD/docker-compose.yml,startup-script=$PWD/gcp/startup.sh \
 --metadata google-logging-enabled=true,cos-metrics-enabled=true,USERNAME=$USERNAME \
 --address $GCE_STATIC_IP_ADDRESS \
 --shielded-secure-boot \
 --shielded-vtpm \
 --shielded-integrity-monitoring

- Disk size: '15 GB' is larger than image size: '10 GB'. You might need to resize the root repartition manually if the operating system does not support automatic resizing. See https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/disks/add-persistent-disk#resize_pd for details.
disk-size 15 VM gcloud compute disks resize BOOT_DISK_NAME --size DISK_SIZE


https://cloud.google.com/container-optimized-os/docs/concepts/disks-and-filesystem#working_with_the_file_system

startup log
code: log
 sudo journalctl -u google-startup-scripts.service

entry.title: Next.js+Prisma+PostgreSQLApp - - Scrapbox
entry.content:
How to Build a Fullstack App with Next.js, Prisma, and PostgreSQL
cf. https://vercel.com/guides/nextjs-prisma-postgres


 Node.js
 PostgreSQL (HerokuPostgreSQL)
 GitHub
  OAuth
 A Vercel Account
  Vercel


Step 1: Set up your Next.js starter project
Step 2: Set up Prisma and connect your PostgreSQL database
Step 3. Create your database schema with Prisma
Step 4. Install and generate Prisma Client
Step 5. Update the existing views to load data from the database
Step 6. Set up GitHub authentication with NextAuth
Step 7. Add Log In functionality

entry.title: Step 4. Install and generate Prisma Client - - Scrapbox
entry.content:
code:terminal
 $ npm install @prisma/client
 $ npx prisma generate

Prisma ClientPrismanpx prisma generate

code:terminal
 $ mkdir lib && touch lib/prisma.ts

prisma.ts prisma lib

code:lib/prisma.ts
 // lib/prisma.ts
 import { PrismaClient } from '@prisma/client';
 
 let prisma: PrismaClient;
 
 if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production') {
   prisma = new PrismaClient();
 } else {
   if (!global.prisma) {
     global.prisma = new PrismaClient();
   }
   prisma = global.prisma;
 }
 
 export default prisma;

Step 5. Update the existing views to load data from the database

entry.title: Step 3. Create your database schema with Prisma - - Scrapbox
entry.content:
code:schema.prisma
 // schema.prisma
 datasource db {
   provider = "postgresql"
   url = env("DATABASE_URL")
 }
 
 generator client {
   provider = "prisma-client-js"
 }
 
 model Post {
   id Int @default(autoincrement()) @id
   title String
   content String?
   published Boolean @default(false)
   author User? @relation(fields: authorId, references: id)
   authorId Int?
 }
 
 model User {
   id Int @default(autoincrement()) @id
   name String?
   email String? @unique
   createdAt DateTime @default(now()) @map(name: "created_at")
   updatedAt DateTime @updatedAt @map(name: "updated_at")
   posts Post[]
   @@map(name: "users")
 }


This Prisma schema defines two models, each of which will map to a table in the underlying database: User and Post. Notice that there's also a relation (one-to-many) between the two models, via the author field on Post and the posts field on User.

User Post

code:terminal
 $ npx prisma db push

PostgreSQL

code:terminal
 $ npx prisma studio

ORM
Next.js

Step 4. Install and generate Prisma Client
